paragraphs.name: 3ce6
paragraphs.text: Over time, we developed a new infinite scrolling component called VirtualScroller. With this new component, we know exactly what slice of Tweets are being rendered into a timeline at any given time, avoiding the need to make expensive calculations as to where we are visually.
It turns out that mounting and unmounting large trees of components (like timelines of Tweets) is very expensive in React.
paragraphs.name: 1f10
4cf6
paragraphs.text: While we use a custom middleware, there are other batch middleware available. Choose the one that’s right for you, or write your own.

paragraphs.name: c295
paragraphs.text: By removing the draft Tweet state from updating the main Redux state on every keypress and keeping things local in the React component’s state, we were able to reduce the overhead by over 50% (above, right).

Over time, we developed a new infinite scrolling component called VirtualScroller. With this new component, we know exactly what slice of Tweets are being rendered into a timeline at any given time, avoiding the need to make expensive calculations as to where we are visually.
paragraphs.name: 3ce6

7fbd7d8b4aba.title: We needed some enhancements, support for redux-thunk, and logging/metrics that are specific to us…

paragraphs.name: 3d96
paragraphs.text: We needed some enhancements, support for redux-thunk, and logging/metrics that are specific to us that we couldn’t get from those available.

c15b05a9e167.title: Chrome’s Developer Tools are our greatest asset in terms of finding and fixing problems.

paragraphs.name: 17f3
paragraphs.text: Chrome’s Developer Tools are our greatest asset in terms of finding and fixing problems. For production, we have lightweight measures of time-to-interactivity (TTI) and time-to-first-tweet (TTFT). These use the window.performance.timings information. We also have a small HOC around specific components that logs React’s mount and update times to an internal system.

758f882329e5.title: So you migrated your storing of input keypress state via Redux reducers to local component state?

paragraphs.name: 8e72
paragraphs.text: So you migrated your storing of input keypress state via Redux reducers to local component state? Do you not need to manage it outside of draft Tweet state for validation or other purposes? If not, what if you needed parent components to have access? Would you send it to the store after idle or timeout?

bb4a9eeb4346.title: VirtualScroller keeps track of what portion of items are being rendered on the screen since it…

paragraphs.name: 693a
paragraphs.text: VirtualScroller keeps track of what portion of items are being rendered on the screen since it requires that information to decide what stays and what goes. We can simply reuse that information without needing to do the calculation again. We also cache item heights so we can avoid computation-heavy Element.getBindingClientRect() as much as possible.

cdc8c2417cc.title: It’s sent places only on componentWillUnmount and submit to avoid any of that overhead while typing…

paragraphs.name: fbdd
paragraphs.text: It’s sent places only on componentWillUnmount and submit to avoid any of that overhead while typing. Most of the validation and logics for the character counter is done inline via twitter-text.
